temperature.title: Temperature
temperature.content:
L. monocytogenes are psychrotrophic bacteria. This means that they can grow in a large range of temperatures, from -2°C to 45°C, although their optimal range is 30 to 37°C. One of their characteristics is that they can survive at very low temperatures, as low as -18°C.
L. monocytogenes are sensitive to heat. For example, at 65°C, the population is divided by 10 in 0.2 to 2 minutes in skimmed milk.

oxygen.title: Oxygen
oxygen.content: L. monocytogenes are facultative anaerobic and microaerophilic organisms. This means that they are able to grow in the presence or absence of oxygen, for example under a vacuum or in a modified gas atmosphere.

ph.title: pH
ph.content:
L. monocytogenes can survive in a wide range of pH conditions from 3.3 to 9.6 and grow optimally at pH 7.0.
EU regulation considers that products with a pH ≤ 4.4 or products with pH ≤ 5.0 and water activity (aw) ≤ 0.94 are unable to support the growth of L. monocytogenes.

humidity.title: Water
humidity.content: L. monocytogenes can grow with a water activity (aw) > 0.92 but can survive in lower water activity. EU regulations consider that products with aw ≤ 0.92 and products with pH ≤ 5.0 and aw ≤ 0.94 are unable to support the growth of L. monocytogenes.

salinity.title: Salinity
salinity.content: L. monocytogenes are able to survive in high salinity concentrations (> 20.0%).
